utterances.utterance: Well, but the truth of the matter is, no one's expecting President -- and I'm sorry. No one's expecting President Trump to be perfect. The Democrats hold up this picture perfection when it comes to their candidates, and they don't allow any room for there to be errors. That's why you talk about progressives like Elizabeth Warren.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Well, they were coming out of the woodwork last night to do just that. I mean, I guess looking at Joe Biden, I mean, they're leaping at it right, Kristen? I guess what I think, if he were the nominee, the playback of some of their comments are going to come back to bite him.

utterances.speaker: HAWN
utterances.utterance: I mean, I think so. He has a long record, and that's something that the campaign is fully prepared for. I do think, by and large, that he has the -- if you look at where he is on the policies and building on the record, the Obama-Biden record, that he's our strongest chance of beating Trump.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: All right, you said record. I say eight-track tape, but let's just split the difference.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Guys, thank you all very, very much.

utterances.speaker: CALDWELL
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: HAWN
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: We have a lot more after this, including, guess what? The Bahamas, they could be facing another storm.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: All right, we are just getting word the attorney general, Bill Barr, has received the draft -- I stress -- the draft report on allegations of FISA abuses from the Department of Justice inspector general, Michael Horowitz, enough in that report for the attorney general to review, maybe pass along the findings of that. It's too early to tell, but the draft at least is in the attorney general's hands. We will keep you posted. In the meantime, keeping you posted on the Bahamas preparing for what could be yet another storm, even as they're still trying to get themselves out of the incredible damage, Category 5 damage, from Dorian. Steve Harrigan in Nassau with the latest -- Steve.

utterances.speaker: STEVE HARRIGAN, CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: Neil, we could be looking at potentially tropical-storm-force winds and up to five inches of rain over the next 48 hours. The problem is where it could hit, the exact islands that were pretty much crushed by Hurricane Dorian less than two weeks ago, that storm moving in Friday into Saturday. And, really, when you look at the situation those northern islands, some of them entire destruction of neighborhoods, tens of thousands of houses gone, and people really just struggling at this point to try to get a foot back on the ground. You see people with no electricity trying to use hammers and nail tarps over gaping holes in their homes. You see people are washing clothes outside, hanging them up on trees. So, really, the last thing they need is another five inches of rain in those conditions. We will watch it closely -- Neil, back to you.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: All right, thank you, my friend, very, very much, Steve Harrigan in the middle of all that. And now they're facing still more problems. Meanwhile, this college admissions scandal back in court, just as kids are applying to go to college. The fallout on them -- after this.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: You know, she did the crime. And a lot of people said that it didn't look like it was serious enough for her to do the time. But it is. The college admissions scandal making headlines again, as actress Felicity Huffman gets 14 days in prison for paying 15,000 bucks to boost her daughter's SAT scores. It didn't work. And now she, at least six weeks from now, is going to be spending 14 days in the big house. All right, young people are getting ready to apply to college in the middle of all of this. So, obviously, it comes at a time of mixed feelings and all of that. We have got "Your World" audio technician and bestselling author Dion Baia, Internet radio sensation Mike Gunzelman, and last, but not least, Fox News contributor, the host of "Sincerely Kat" on FOX Nation, Kat Timpf. Welcome to all. I guess the big surprise, Dion, was that she's doing time.

utterances.speaker: DION BAIA, AUDIO TECHNICIAN
utterances.utterance: Yes, I mean, I think she did the right thing, because she didn't -- she automatically said, OK, I'm guilty, I'm culpable, I'm ready to make a deal, and admitted her guilt, and was ready to accept the punishment.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: And even after that. That's when I think it really registers, if after your -- the punishment is meted out, and you deny -- she said, I got what I deserve.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MIKE GUNZELMAN, INTERNET RADIO HOST
utterances.utterance: I have a different take. I think that she didn't get enough time. I think, once again, it pays to be a celebrity and have money, because 14 days is literally nothing.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Well, I think the statute is a 30-day, regardless if you're...

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.utterance: Right, but I think it's just here we have something that she blatantly did something wrong. I mean, even Martha Stewart, she got five months. Mike "The Situation" from "Jersey Shore" got eight months for tax evasion. Like, this is something, you literally took somebody else's, perhaps their dream, their goal, and took it from them. And, like, we have a crime here, and it was proven. And 14 days is nothing for this person.

utterances.speaker: KATHERINE TIMPF, CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: She's lucky. I think she's so lucky that she gets to go to prison for 14 days. Like, I mean, if you go to prison, you get a little bit of street cred. You can maybe write a book about it. But 14 days, that's manageable. I'm kind of interested in this business model. Like, what can I do to go to prison, but only for 14 days? I'm worried I might miscalculate, and then I'm locked up forever.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Can't someone be genuinely apologetic and feel remorse? And can't any of you just move on?

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.utterance: Well, no, you know she doesn't believe that. She's really not.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: You don't know that.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.utterance: She will get a book deal. She will get a reality show out of this. I mean, come on now.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: I think the real victims here are the people who did lose out on the scholarships. In the other case with Lori Loughlin...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: But you liken it to those with a wink and a nod are going to give school money and all that?

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Well, I feel really bad for the people who are culpable who are taking fake pictures, rowing photos.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Well, that's a different one.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: I know, but it's still lumped into this whole...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: I just wonder. In this season, when the kids are going back -- or applying to these colleges, whether everyone is going to be doubly aware of not looking like their crossing a line.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.utterance: And if there's anything -- you know, parents are so protective of their children. I mean, the parents go nuts about cheerleading squads and athletics in high school. Be like, oh, this is my -- this is my kid. They deserve this. They deserve this.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Well, my son is going to through this right now. And I told him, I said, I am not going to pay your way to a community college. It's not happening.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: The big issue here was -- too, was that the parents -- I don't know about Huffman, but wasn't it that they didn't think that they did anything wrong? With Lori Loughlin, she was like, I didn't -- I was doing what any parent would do.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: What anyone...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Yes. And now they know. Now they know.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: In the meantime, the crackdown on vaping, is it justified to go after all of these products because they're deemed a threat to kids? What do you guys think?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Well, everybody knows what I think. I think it's awful. I...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: What is awful?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: It's awful. Well, vaping is awful. And I know because I can't stop doing it. But I have the freedom to ruin my own life in a free country.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: So, you don't want anyone in the government taking products away because they're a danger to you or could be?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Absolutely, especially because a lot of this has been hysteria, with all these headlines saying vaping illnesses, deaths from vaping. They do not specifically say that 83 percent of these people admitted that they were also vaping black market THC products, not these legal nicotine products. So I think that that's really missing the point. And cigarettes are still legal. And we know those are bad.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: I think that people are really worried about, how 60 years ago, the tobacco industry -- if you go and look on YouTube, you have like the "Flintstones" commercials, "Like, hey, Fred, you smoking a Winston Light?" It's like, "Yeah, Barney."

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: But wasn't vaping supposed to be a way to cut down...

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.utterance: And it does. People do lean off of cigarettes by vaping. But I don't think the government...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: So, if we take them all off the market, then you could be exposing these people to the dangers of...

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.utterance: Of the black market ones or even the bootleg ones. But I don't think the government should -- should regulate and ban vaping and e-cigs.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.utterance: Like, what is that? That's a way overstretch. Maybe inform children more, but don't ban it.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: And don't have them go after kids with their marketing, like, oh, here's a watermelon, here's a raspberry.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: No, that watermelon is delicious, actually.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: A lot of issues.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Kat Timpf, our vaping editor.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
